interrupt_usart_example.c File Reference

Detailed Description

Example of an interrupt-driven USART communication.

This file contains an example using the USART module with interrupts.

It will display a string on the screen. Refer to the usart_options structure in main for configuration options for your terminal.

Please make sure that the correct jumper(s) is/are set on your development board. Refer to your hardware reference guide if necessary.

  • Compiler: IAR EWAVR32 and GNU GCC for AVR32
  • Supported devices: All AVR32 devices with an INTC module can be used.
  • AppNote:

Author:
Atmel Corporation: http://www.atmel.com
Support and FAQ: http://support.atmel.no/

Function Documentation

int main ( void   ) 

The main function.

It sets up the USART module on EXAMPLE_USART. The terminal settings are 57600 8N1. Then it sets up the interrupt handler and waits for a USART interrupt to trigger.

References EXAMPLE_USART, EXAMPLE_USART_IRQ, EXAMPLE_USART_RX_FUNCTION, EXAMPLE_USART_RX_PIN, EXAMPLE_USART_TX_FUNCTION, EXAMPLE_USART_TX_PIN, INT0, INTC_init_interrupts(), INTC_register_interrupt(), and usart_int_handler().

00177 {
00178   static const gpio_map_t USART_GPIO_MAP =
00179   {
00180     {EXAMPLE_USART_RX_PIN, EXAMPLE_USART_RX_FUNCTION},
00181     {EXAMPLE_USART_TX_PIN, EXAMPLE_USART_TX_FUNCTION}
00182   };
00183 
00184   // USART options.
00185   static const usart_options_t USART_OPTIONS =
00186   {
00187     .baudrate     = 57600,
00188     .charlength   = 8,
00189     .paritytype   = USART_NO_PARITY,
00190     .stopbits     = USART_1_STOPBIT,
00191     .channelmode  = USART_NORMAL_CHMODE
00192   };
00193 
00194   // Switch main clock to external oscillator 0 (crystal).
00195   pm_switch_to_osc0(&AVR32_PM, FOSC0, OSC0_STARTUP);
00196 
00197   // Assign GPIO to USART.
00198   gpio_enable_module(USART_GPIO_MAP,
00199                      sizeof(USART_GPIO_MAP) / sizeof(USART_GPIO_MAP[0]));
00200 
00201   // Initialize USART in RS232 mode.
00202   usart_init_rs232(EXAMPLE_USART, &USART_OPTIONS, FOSC0);
00203   print(EXAMPLE_USART, ".: Using interrupts with the USART :.\n\n");
00204 
00205   // Disable all interrupts.
00206   Disable_global_interrupt();
00207 
00208   // Initialize interrupt vectors.
00209   INTC_init_interrupts();
00210 
00211   // Register the USART interrupt handler to the interrupt controller.
00212   // usart_int_handler is the interrupt handler to register.
00213   // EXAMPLE_USART_IRQ is the IRQ of the interrupt handler to register.
00214   // INT0 is the interrupt priority level to assign to the group of this IRQ.
00215   // void INTC_register_interrupt(__int_handler handler, unsigned int irq, unsigned int int_lev);
00216   INTC_register_interrupt(&usart_int_handler, EXAMPLE_USART_IRQ, INT0);
00217 
00218   // Enable USART Rx interrupt.
00219   EXAMPLE_USART->ier = AVR32_USART_IER_RXRDY_MASK;
00220   print(EXAMPLE_USART, "Type a character to use the interrupt handler.\n"
00221                        "It will show up on your screen.\n\n");
00222 
00223   // Enable all interrupts.
00224   Enable_global_interrupt();
00225 
00226   while (TRUE);
00227 }

static void usart_int_handler ( void   )  [static]

The USART interrupt handler.

Note:
The `__attribute__((__interrupt__))' (under GNU GCC for AVR32) and `__interrupt' (under IAR Embedded Workbench for Atmel AVR32) C function attributes are used to manage the `rete' instruction.

Definition at line 146 of file interrupt_usart_example.c.

References EXAMPLE_USART.

Referenced by main().

00147 {
00148   int c;
00149 
00150   // In the code line below, the interrupt priority level does not need to be
00151   // explicitly masked as it is already because we are within the interrupt
00152   // handler.
00153   // The USART Rx interrupt flag is cleared by side effect when reading the
00154   // received character.
00155   // Waiting until the interrupt has actually been cleared is here useless as
00156   // the call to usart_write_char will take enough time for this before the
00157   // interrupt handler is leaved and the interrupt priority level is unmasked by
00158   // the CPU.
00159   usart_read_char(EXAMPLE_USART, &c);
00160 
00161   // Print the received character to USART.
00162   // It is a simple echo, so there will be no translation of '\r' to "\r\n". The
00163   // connected terminal has to be configured accordingly to send '\n' after
00164   // '\r'.
00165   usart_write_char(EXAMPLE_USART, c);
00166 }
